summary: A letter from an unidentified author (likely Jeffrey Epstein) to Alberto expressing disappointment over Alberto's attempted resignation from a construction project on an island property. The author demands project completion, references delays, expenses, and involves other individuals like Jean and Cabinet Pinto.

persons.name: Alberto
persons.context: Addressed in a letter regarding his attempted resignation from an island construction project; accused of leaving the job unfinished and failing to communicate.

persons.name: Jean
persons.context: Referenced as someone who assured project completion by end of July but has not contacted the author; described as an employee.

persons.name: Cabinet Pinto
persons.context: Mentioned as the entity with which the author has a total relationship, implying Alberto's obligation through them.

connections.description: Alberto appears to be in a supervisory or contractual role over Jean, who is described as an employee on the island project.
Alberto's obligations are tied to Cabinet Pinto, with the author stating the relationship is with Cabinet Pinto, not Jean.
Author expresses disappointment over Alberto's resignation attempt and demands completion of the island project, referencing a friendship and prior assurances.

events.title: Island Project Delays and Resignation Attempt
events.description: Alberto attempted to resign from an island construction project, leading to a letter from the author demanding completion and citing missed deadlines (originally for last Christmas, then end of July).

locations: Island property (likely Little St. James or similar Epstein-associated island)
Living room of the house under construction
keyFacts: The author references an 'island project' with significant interior purchases, permits, and drawings in a Moroccan style, indicating substantial investment.
Alberto is accused of leaving the project in a state of disrepair and failing to communicate despite prior promises.
The author emphasizes a personal and familial relationship with Alberto, stating it's not simple to abandon a 'family member'.
Jean is identified as an employee who assured completion by end of July but has not contacted the author.
The author's tone suggests frustration over broken commitments and financial losses, demanding immediate action to finish the house.
